title: Lesson 8: Cytoskeleton and Cell Walls
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding the cytoskeleton's role in cell structure and movement, and comparing cell wall composition across bacteria, fungi, plants, and animals.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the structure and function of the cytoskeleton (microtubules, microfilaments).
Students can compare the cell wall composition of plants (cellulose), fungi (chitin), and bacteria (peptidoglycan).
Students can explain why animal cells lack cell walls and how the cytoskeleton provides support instead.

engagementHook.title: The Bone and Muscle of the Cell
engagementHook.content: Show video of amoeba moving (crawling) vs. plant cell with rigid walls. 'How does the amoeba change shape without a wall? And why can trees grow 100m tall without bones? Today we explore the cytoskeleton (cellular muscles and bones) and the walls that surround cells.'

keyConcepts.definition: Network of protein filaments providing shape, support, and movement. Includes microtubules, microfilaments, and intermediate filaments.
Hollow tubes (tubulin protein). Form cilia, flagella (9+2 arrangement), spindle fibres for cell division, and tracks for organelle movement.
Solid threads. Muscle contraction, cell division (cleavage furrow), amoeboid movement.
Rigid outer layers outside the plasma membrane. Plants: cellulose; Fungi: chitin; Bacteria: peptidoglycan; Animals: none.
Channels through plant cell walls connecting adjacent cells.

misconceptions.correction: Cell walls are non-living secretions outside the plasma membrane. The living part is the cell membrane and cytoplasm.

misconceptions.misconception: All cell walls are the same
misconceptions.correction: Emphasise the three different chemicals (cellulose, chitin, peptidoglycan) and that animal cells lack them entirely.
Also for structure and shape—like a skeleton for the cell.

contentSections.title: The Cytoskeleton Network
contentSections.content: Cell showing microtubules (radiating from centre), microfilaments (cortex/mesh), intermediate filaments (structural).
keyPoints: Microtubules (hollow, tubulin) for shape and transport
contentSections.example: Cancer drugs (taxol) target microtubules to stop cell division; cystic fibrosis affects microtubule transport (cilia in lungs).

contentSections.title: Cilia and Flagella (Eukaryotic)
contentSections.content: Microtubule-based structures (9+2 arrangement) for cell movement. Different from bacterial flagella (protein filament, no microtubules—recall Lesson 1).
contentSections.example: Tracheal cilia sweep mucus (with trapped dust/bacteria) out of lungs; sperm flagella for swimming.

shortAnswer.question: Compare the cell wall composition of bacteria and plant cells. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Plant walls contain cellulose (fibrous polysaccharide providing rigidity)

shortAnswer.question: Describe the role of microtubules in eukaryotic cells. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Provide structural support/maintain cell shape OR form tracks for organelle movement
1 mark: Form spindle fibres during cell division OR form structure of cilia and flagella (9+2 arrangement)

definitions: The cytoskeleton includes microtubules (shape, transport, division) and microfilaments (movement).
Plant cell walls contain cellulose; fungal walls contain chitin; bacterial walls contain peptidoglycan.
Animal cells lack cell walls, allowing flexibility and movement.
Eukaryotic cilia and flagella contain microtubules (9+2 structure).
Cell walls are non-living structures outside the cell membrane.
keyPoints: Microtubules = hollow tubes made of tubulin
Microfilaments = actin fibres for muscle and movement
9+2 arrangement in eukaryotic flagella (different from bacterial)
diagrams: Cytoskeleton network showing three filament types

shortAnswer: Bacterial cell walls are composed of peptidoglycan, which forms a rigid mesh structure that provides protection and shape. Plant cell walls are composed of cellulose, a fibrous polysaccharide that provides rigidity and structural support while preventing the cell from bursting in hypotonic solutions.

Microtubules are hollow tubes made of tubulin protein that provide structural support and maintain cell shape. They also form the spindle fibres during cell division and make up the internal structure of cilia and flagella (arranged in a 9+2 pattern). Additionally, they act as tracks for organelle movement within the cell.
